REANIMAL is the latest game from Tarsier Studios, the creators of Little Nightmares. While Little Nightmares 3 was released around the same time, REANIMAL feels more like a true spiritual successor. It immerses you in the same vast, unsettling, and atmospheric world, where you take on the role of a small, vulnerable character - a constant reminder of your own insignificance. Everyday objects loom large and pose genuine threats, transforming simple navigation into a tense, cinematic ordeal. For an even deeper experience, you can invite a friend to join your adventure.
This was absolutely terrifying AND VERY VERY exciting to play.

Gameplay mechanics and atmosphere feel almost identical to Little Nightmares II.....I mean this in the best way possible!! For what we know and guess, this might be intentional so that both Little Nightmares and REANIMAL can link. 
Nevertheless, you can just tell and feel from this demo alone that the fully finished game is gonna have a very well developed and twisted narrative with its own unique elements and interesting characters.

Can't wait for this gem to drop!!

Also, knowing that one of the new publishers is behind my all time favourite childhood game(SpongeBob Squarepants Battle for Bikkini Bottom) makes me lose it. I first played that game when I was only 4-5 on my PS2. xD

Definitively will be playing the full game and cannot wait till January's full release - thank you for a thrilling and artful experience!

A beautiful follow-up from the team behind Little Nightmares and Little Nightmares 2 (Little Nightmares 3 was someone else).

My only complaint was that the game looks basically identical on high vs. ultra graphics settings, but ultra slows my game to a crawl while high doesn't. (I have an NVIDIA RTX 3070, so I should be able to play a 2D game at the highest settings no problem.) This game was developed on Unreal Engine 5, so it's not really their fault, and I'd definitely rather have a poorly-optimized game than no game, but still.

Very cinematic, and the 2.5-D perspective opens up many new puzzle possibilities. I also liked the grotesque monsters and generally disgusting setting (though I couldn't work out how to remove a hat I found in an in-game toilet and so wound up playing most of the game with a pile of intestines on my character's head). I hope Playdead (the studio behind Limbo and Inside) is watching and taking notes for their own third game!

Let me start by saying this: I love games. I live for the thrill of exploration, the satisfaction of overcoming challenges, and the immersion of stepping into new worlds. But your game? It turned that joy into a soul-crushing cycle of frustrationâ€”all because you decided to reinvent the wheel on a control scheme so basic, itâ€™s been universal since the dawn of 3D gaming.
For hours, I died. Over and over and over. Not because the boss was too hard. Not because I lacked skill. Because your game refuses to use Shift for running. Let that sink in. Every single major gameâ€”from RPGs to shooters, platformers to open-world epicsâ€”has trained players for decades that Shift = sprint. Itâ€™s not just a convention; itâ€™s muscle memory. Itâ€™s the kind of control that feels as natural as breathing when youâ€™re in the heat of the moment. But you? You thought, â€œHey, letâ€™s make players fumble around for 45 minutes straight, dying to enemies they canâ€™t outrun, because weâ€™re edgy or lazy or just donâ€™t care about user experience.â€
I wasnâ€™t just annoyedâ€”I was baffled. How do you mess up something so fundamental? Did none of you test this with actual players? Did you sit in a meeting room and go, â€œForget what everyone else does; letâ€™s make running a different key just because we canâ€? Spoiler: Thatâ€™s not innovation. Thatâ€™s arrogance. Youâ€™re forcing players to unlearn years of gaming instincts for no good reason, and it ruins the entire opening experience. By the time I finally gave up and searched for a æ”»ç•¥ (walkthrough)â€”something I never do unless a game is actively hostile to its playersâ€”I was so drained, I almost quit entirely.
Hereâ€™s a newsflash: Good game design isnâ€™t about being â€œuniqueâ€ at the cost of usability. Itâ€™s about meeting players where they are. Itâ€™s about not making them fight the controls while theyâ€™re trying to fight the gameâ€™s challenges. You want to stand out? Do it with story, with gameplay mechanics, with artâ€”not by breaking a control scheme thatâ€™s worked for 20 years.
To whoever made this call: I hope youâ€™re proud. You turned a potentially great game into a source of frustration, all because you thought your â€œcreative visionâ€ was more important than player comfort. Next time, maybe ask yourself: Is making players Google basic controls really the first impression you want to leave? Spoiler two: Itâ€™s not.

I'm genuinely baffled this has overwhelmingly positive. It's nearly unplayable for my partner and I. Maybe it's just bad luck, but the level involving a minecart entirely breaks the game. I desync entirely on the same staircase and there is no fixing it. Rebooting fixes until the moment I reach that same staircase, then it breaks. Easily replicated and without falter. This wouldn't be an issue if progress was saved between players, but it's not. This means nearly an hour has to be redone. It's not hard, and it's not a lot of progress, but it also shouldn't be an issue in the first place.

The controller also has a tendency to just stop working in the menu. Both my partner and I had to immediately reboot the game, as the menu instantly stopped working with controller. After managing to get Remote Play to work, there were more issues. The controller problem carried over into the game, so I had to reboot another time and try to get things to work all over again. When we got that working, characters kept switching at random. This is a real problem when you're being chased, since you start running into a wall and find yourself stuck.

The game is gorgeous, and plays exactly as you'd expect if you enjoyed LIttle Nightmares. But it borders on unplayable right now. I guess most people aren't having this issue, but that's really bad. This demo has been out for days, but what is essentially the first level is unpassable. 

As for optimization, it runs well enough, but it does stutter everytime a new zone loads. Stairs, doors, everything. This is just not in a good place if you're seemingly unlucky. It was such a headache to play this incredibly short demo with my wife, and very much sucked the fun out of the experience.

Will be looking forwards to where this title goes from here besides the game-breaking co-op bug.

I'm genuinely baffled this has overwhelmingly positive. It's nearly unplayable for my partner and I. Maybe it's just bad luck, but the level involving a minecart entirely breaks the game. I desync entirely on the same staircase and there is no fixing it. Rebooting fixes until the moment I reach that same staircase, then it breaks. Easily replicated and without falter. This wouldn't be an issue if progress was saved between players, but it's not. This means nearly an hour has to be redone. It's not hard, and it's not a lot of progress, but it also shouldn't be an issue in the first place.

The controller also has a tendency to just stop working in the menu. Both my partner and I had to immediately reboot the game, as the menu instantly stopped working with controller. After managing to get Remote Play to work, there were more issues. The controller problem carried over into the game, so I had to reboot another time and try to get things to work all over again. When we got that working, characters kept switching at random. This is a real problem when you're being chased, since you start running into a wall and find yourself stuck.

The game is gorgeous, and plays exactly as you'd expect if you enjoyed LIttle Nightmares. But it borders on unplayable right now. I guess most people aren't having this issue, but that's really bad. This demo has been out for days, but what is essentially the first level is unpassable. 

As for optimization, it runs well enough, but it does stutter everytime a new zone loads. Stairs, doors, everything. This is just not in a good place if you're seemingly unlucky. It was such a headache to play this incredibly short demo with my wife, and very much sucked the fun out of the experience.
looks like a cool game so far but bugged for online co-op at the factory level, my character just runs into the corner on my partners screen and we cant progress through the level.

Demo completely desync's and becomes unplayable in co-op so far, game design and everything else seems great. I see a lot of reviews saying its just after the cart section but happened to us almost from the jump. Clearly this needs a lot more testing and work. Otherwise I can see the game being fantastic, had a few major fps drops here and there. Would've like the co-op to not share a camera as well, although I can see where that's a choice for the game's design especially if there's local co-op. Will be looking forwards to where this title goes from here besides the game-breaking co-op bug.

Great artwork and atmosphere and I really wanted to like it, but after the nth time getting stuck by a peace of wood/metal/invisible step, just because of the controls and laggy camera, I got frustrated.

The game doesn't seem that hard, but the controls and camera made it extremely frustrating for me, I'm getting older and have less patience and time for these kind of annoyances. Just wanted to be frightened and entertained. :-)

For everyone else, have fun

I'm genuinely baffled this has overwhelmingly positive. It's nearly unplayable for my partner and I. Maybe it's just bad luck, but the level involving a minecart entirely breaks the game. I desync entirely on the same staircase and there is no fixing it. Rebooting fixes until the moment I reach that same staircase, then it breaks. Easily replicated and without falter. This wouldn't be an issue if progress was saved between players, but it's not. This means nearly an hour has to be redone. It's not hard, and it's not a lot of progress, but it also shouldn't be an issue in the first place.

The controller also has a tendency to just stop working in the menu. Both my partner and I had to immediately reboot the game, as the menu instantly stopped working with controller. After managing to get Remote Play to work, there were more issues. The controller problem carried over into the game, so I had to reboot another time and try to get things to work all over again. When we got that working, characters kept switching at random. This is a real problem when you're being chased, since you start running into a wall and find yourself stuck.

The game is gorgeous, and plays exactly as you'd expect if you enjoyed LIttle Nightmares. But it borders on unplayable right now. I guess most people aren't having this issue, but that's really bad. This demo has been out for days, but what is essentially the first level is unpassable. 

As for optimization, it runs well enough, but it does stutter everytime a new zone loads. Stairs, doors, everything. This is just not in a good place if you're seemingly unlucky. It was such a headache to play this incredibly short demo with my wife, and very much sucked the fun out of the experience.
